reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

description.narrative: Kiinassa ei ole LBT-naisia suojelevaa tai kriminalisoivaa lainsäädäntöä. Sorto on usein sosiaalisiin rakenteisiin piilotettua. Kiinalaisen yhteiskunnan ja ydinperheiden arvot luovat institutionaalista ennakkoluuloa. Common Language -järjestön tutkim uksen mukaan 48 % tutkimukseen osallistuneista oli kokenut väkivaltaan ydinperheen jäsen toimesta seksuaalisen suuntautumisensa vuoksi. Sosiaalisen tuen puuttumisen vuoksi LBT-naisten on vaikea löytää tarvittavia tukipalveluita ja he ovat usein joutu neet syrjinnän kohteeksi myös paikallisten naisjärjestöjen sekä toimesta.Kiinan perheväkivaltaläinsäädäntöä uudistetaan parhallaan mutta lainsäädäntö sekä sen paikallinen toteutus ei tunnusta tai suojela LBT-naisia perheväkivallalta. Hank keen tavoitteena on sisällyttää LBT-naisten suojelu perheväkivaltaa koskevaan lainsäädäntöön sekä paikallistason toteutukseen tukijärjestelmän luominen perhevälivallan uhreille pilottialueilla sekä lisätä kansalaisjärjestöjen kapasiteetti a perheväkivallan uhrien puolustamiseksi.

There are no specific laws that protect or criminalize lesbian bisexual and trans* (LBT) women in China. Oppression for LBT individuals is often hidden social structures like the heterosexual family and filial piety exclude and marginalize non-traditional sexual and gender identities. These values and practices drive institutional prejudice at all levels in Chinese society and the core family unit is commonly the perpetrator of violence against LBT individuals.In 2009 Common Language conducted a survey that revealed 48% of participants were victim to violence from family members as a result of exposed sexual orientation. Due to pervasive discrimination and stigma against lesbians and gays in Chinese society LBT women face extreme social pressures leading to high rates of intimate partner violence. In the afore-mentioned 2009 survey 46% of participants had experienced violence from a same-sex intimate partner. The violence in the report took the form of battery involuntary captivity economic control forced mar riage marital rape sexual violence perpetrated by family members involuntary commitment into mental hospitals and ?conversion therapy? to ?cure? homosexuals. Due to limited social support LBT women who are survivors of violence find it difficult to access adequate services; in fact in the process of reaching out to local Women?s Federations or police departments some survivors were again discriminated against on the basis of their sexual orientation.The national anti-domestic violence (DV) law in China is c urrently being legislated but currently most local regulations fail to recognize or protect LBT women from domestic violence. In addition lack of accurate information and understanding of the needs of LBT women among relevant stakeholders (women?s federati on police state prosecutors judges) and limited capacity of these stakeholders to prevent and/or intervene in instances of family violence against LBT women are also two big challenges to LBT women to protect their rights. The objectives of the project are I) Legal experts and key stakeholders support inclusion of the protection of LBT women in the legislation of the national level DV law and its subsequent local implementation II) Multi-sector community support and referral made available in pilot areas to combat family violence against LBT women III) Increased capacity of CBOs to defend the rights of LBT individuals in response to DV.
